TextView.android:text: Android 1.0 (2008): The initial release with basic features like the Android Market and support for Google Maps

Android 1.5 (Cupcake, 2009): Introduced an on-screen keyboard, video recording, and third-party app widgets.\nAndroid 1.6 (Donut, 2009): Added support for different screen sizes, improved camera features, and introduced the Android Market search functionality.

Android 2.0/2.1 (Eclair, 2009-2010): Brought a new user interface, improved Google Maps, and support for multiple accounts.\nAndroid 2.2 (Froyo, 2010): Enhanced performance with the introduction of the JIT compiler, support for Adobe Flash, and Wi-Fi hotspot functionality.

Android 2.3 (Gingerbread, 2010): Introduced a refreshed user interface, improved gaming, and better support for front-facing cameras.\nAndroid 3.0 (Honeycomb, 2011): Designed specifically for tablets with a new holographic user interface and improved multitasking.\nAndroid 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich, 2011): Unified the phone and tablet UI, introduced a new design language, and added features like facial recognition.

Android 4.1/4.2/4.3 (Jelly Bean, 2012-2013): Focused on performance improvements with Project Butter, introduced Google Now, and enhanced notifications.
Android 4.4 (KitKat, 2013): Optimized performance for lower-end devices, introduced the Ok Google voice command, and revamped the user interface.
Android 5.0/5.1 (Lollipop, 2014-2015): Brought Material Design for a consistent look across apps and devices, introduced improved notifications and battery life features.
Android 6.0 (Marshmallow, 2015): Added features like Doze mode for battery savings, improved permissions management, and Google Now on Tap.

Android 7.0/7.1 (Nougat, 2016-2017): Introduced split-screen multitasking, improved notifications, and enhanced security features.
Android 8.0/8.1 (Oreo, 2017): Added features like picture-in-picture mode, notification dots, and improved battery optimization.
Android 9.0 (Pie, 2018): Introduced gesture navigation, adaptive battery and brightness, and improved security features.
Android 10 (2019): Dropped dessert names for versioning, introduced a system-wide dark mode, and improved privacy controls.

Android 11 (2020): Focused on user control and privacy with features like one-time permissions, improved notifications, and better support for 5G.
Android 12 (2021): Brought a major visual overhaul with Material You, enhanced privacy features, and improved performance.
Android 13 (2022): Continued with user customization, expanded support for foldable devices, and refined security and privacy features.
Android 14 (2023): Introduced enhancements in device compatibility, improved performance, and further refined user interface and security features.
